bioghist.p: Mathew Carey (1760-1839) founded Mathew Carey & Co. in 1785. The firm went on to become Philadelphia's most successful publishing house, printing the works of Thomas Jefferson, Parson Weems, Walter Scott, James Fenimore Cooper, and the first quarto Bible of American manufacture, then moving on to specialize in scientific and medical publication by the late 1830s. The firm changed its name a number of times. It became M. Carey & Son in 1817, when Mathew's son, Henry C. Carey, joined the firm. In 1821, Carey's son-in-law, Isaac Lea joined the firm and it became M. Carey & Sons. The senior Carey retired in 1824, and shortly thereafter the partnership became Carey, Lea & Carey, when younger son Edward L. Carey joined the firm. In 1829, Edward Carey withdrew to form a bookselling partnership with Abraham Hart. In 1833, William A. Blanchard became a partner and the firm became, briefly, Carey, Lea & Blanchard. In 1836, Henry C. Carey retired and the firm was known as Lea & Blanchard until 1851. That year Isaac Lea withdrew in favor of his son, Henry Charles Lea, and the firm became Blanchard & Lea, which it remained until Blanchard's retirement in 1865. Thereafter, the firm bore only the Lea name until 1907 when Lea's sons joined with Christian Febiger to form the partnership of Lea & Febiger. The company was sold to Waverly, Inc. in 1990.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers related to the Lea and Febiger publishing firm. Materials include: correspondence; author agreements and contracts, 1878-1946; partnership agreements, 1824-1989; registration and transfers of copyrights, 1838-1990; records pertaining to the publication of the History of All Nations and centenary editions of Gray's Anatomy; sales and distribution agreements, 1900-1990; financial volumes including a general ledger (1856-1860), cost book (1910-1955), book inventories (1968-1993), and royalty accounts (1932-36); catalogues, publication lists, and brochures; newspaper clippings, articles, photographs, and documentation of the company's history, including a photograph album of the 200th anniversary celebration; and several woodcuts and brass dies for Gray's Anatomy. The collection also includes a small batch of the correspondence of Mathew Carey. Notable correspondents include the Marquis de Lafayette and James Madison.
